titleStmt.title: Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Pennsylvania University Museum, E 16264 K

respStmt.resp: Edited by Michael Marx in collaboration with Tobias J. Jocham et. al. TEI version created by Yasmin Faghihi and Huw Jones

availability.p: Image credits: Courtesy of Pennsylvania University Museum Philadelphia.

summary.p: 1 fol. on parchment; Shelfmark: E 16264 K; Qurʾānic Text: Q 54:11-54:15, Q 54:34-54:37; 4 lines per page (orig. 19 lines); Dimensions: 195 x 101mm (orig. 260 x 320mm); Script style: kūfī B I b; Estimated date of production: 650-750.

The parchment fragment, which contains some words from the text of sura 54, is kept in the papyrus collection of the University of Pennsylvania Museum. Six other fragments from the same codex are known: (1) Arabe 335 (Paris), (2) Marcel 5 (Saint Petersburg), (3) Cod. Or. 14.545 a (Leiden), (4) Chicago A 6959, (5) KFQ 50 (Khalil Collection London) and (6) MS.276 (Museum of Islamic Arts, Doha, Qatar). The manuscript was originally located in al-Fusṭāṭ (Old Cairo). A radiocarbon measurement of a sample from the Leiden fragment (Cod. Or. 14.545 a) has revealed a date of origin of the parchment cf. Marx/Jocham 2019). Parchment samples of fol. 2/3 and fol. 4 have the following dates: 1322,24 BP and 1335,24 BP respectively. According to the calibration of Oxcal 2020: 653-706 CE, 737-775 CE (95,4 % probability) and 650-703 CE, 741-774 CE (95,4 % probability). Images of the fragment are available on the website of the Arabic Papyrus Collection of the University of Pennsylvania at http://ccat.sas.upenn.edu/rak/ppenn/museum/arabic/16264-K.jpg.

/* Style Definitions */ table.MsoNormalTable {mso-style-name:"Normale Tabelle"; mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0; mso-tstyle-colband-size:0; mso-style-noshow:yes; mso-style-priority:99; mso-style-parent:""; mso-padding-alt:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt; mso-para-margin:0cm; mso-pagination:widow-orphan; mso-hyphenate:none; font-size:11.0pt; font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif; mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri; mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-bidi-font-family:Arial; mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi; mso-font-kerning:1.0pt; mso-ligatures:standardcontextual; mso-fareast-language:EN-US;}
The catalogue of Arabic manuscripts kept by the University Museums in Philaldelphia, written by Giorgio Levi Della Vida gives the following information (Levi Della Vida 1981, p. 152f.):

"126. Inv. E 16264 K. 3rd century A. H./9th century A. D. White, thin parchment. 10.1 x 19.5 cm. Written in black ink on both faces, four broken lines to the page. Middle part of the inner half of a sheet which must have contained nineteen lines to the page, and the original size of which must have been ca. 32 x 26 cm. From the Ellen W. Harrison Collection. Recto: Kor. 54,11 ابوٰب – 15 و[لقد]. Verso: 54,34 آل – 37 اعينهم. The script is large, heavy and stiff; it presents a great similarity with no. 9 in the Chicago Collection (see The Rise of the North Arabic Script, p. 64 and Plate XV). The alifs, the lower ends of which are slightly bent towards the right, measure ca. 2.4 cm. yāʾ is reversed. Diacritical signs are represented by thin slanting strokes, vowels by red dots, most of which have disappeared. Small lozenges (originally painted red?) are used as verse dividers."
The transliteration of the Arabic text has been produced by Salome Beridze.

This manuscript represents the early kūfī script style B.Ib. The main difference between the styles B.Ia and B.Ib is that in case of the B.Ia group the shaft of ʾalif and other vertical strokes slope to the right (See Déroche, 1992). The letter ʾalif in the manuscript is vertical. As for the letter group ǧīm/ḥāʾ/ḫāʾ in the isolated position, they show resemblance to the script style ḥiǧāzī IV as the horizontal tail is alongated and ends in a short hook. The final letter ʿayn also shares features with the ḥiǧāzī IV group, the body of the letter is more pronounced and angular, than in B.I. In the initial position, the letter shows a round upper curve closer to the B.II group. The initial ʿayn of the B.I group has a short angular hook. The same is the case for the letter in the medial position: the two antennas are hardly distinguishable, the right hand antenna being vertical, as in B.II. The qāf isolated or in the final position shows again a different form, the body is more cursive and less vertical than in B.I.
Oblique strokes are marking the diacritica of the script. The qāf is marked by a dot below the letter, as in most early kūfī Qur'an manuscripts. The vocalisation is done by red dots. (Salome Beridze)
